title: Tuesday, 10th July, 2018

https://www.ft.com...-a29d-73e3d454535d

Rupert Murdoch’s 21st Century Fox is preparing a new bid for Sky that would value it at about £25bn in a clear sign it is committed to beating Comcast in the race to acquire the pan-European pay television group.

Fox is preparing to make the new bid as soon as this week if, as expected, its earlier bid for Sky to be formally approved by the UK government.

BE11:11am

Fox is expected to pitch the new offer at a premium to the most recent bid from US cable group Comcast, which has offered £12.50 a share, according to two people briefed on the matter.

Soundbuy Watch your wallet though.........
pancakes or waffles @Arash it's coming home
Arash Massoudi, FT Yes, got a few phone calls on this, as expected.
11:11 am

Want to put a ballpark figure on "a premium"?

Sky PLC (SKY:LSE): Last: 1,501, up 32.5 (+2.21%), High: 1,501, Low: 1,476, Volume: 1.03m
BE11:12am

Gone through £15! That looks a bit punchy, no?

Arash Massoudi, FT In December 2016, Sky is worth £10.75 a share. July 2018, it now trades above £15
Arash Massoudi, FT @BornCynic I think I have a log-in somewhere. It's just more fun to cause trouble on the right.
Arash Massoudi, FT @BE very punchy. One fundamental point to understand. Disney is willing to spend $71bn for Fox + a huge amount to acquire Sky. In other words, close to $100bn to keep pace with Netflix. It's simply extraordinary.
BornCynic At least BE will not zap you........
chopper bear icap reaction seems a bit steep
11:15 am
BE11:15am

.... $71bn plus the $14bn in Fox debt

Upaswellasdown @arash - are you actually sitting next to Bryce?
Arash Massoudi, FT @BE The question is how far will this go. The merger arbs and hedge fund are willing to bet that there are further Comcast bids for both Fox and Sky still to come. That's what the share price is telling folks.
BE11:16am

There's an attractive logic to using Sky as an offset to the ticket price, though it gets a bit tricky to follow for my old brain.

MonkeyTrader Worth noting that Disney will probably raise about $20bn from selling the Regional Sports Networks that it has offered to sell as part of its agreement with the DOJ.
BE11:17am

Quick quote from Macquarie, last week.

Arash Massoudi, FT @Upaswellasdown -- I'm about 20 feet away.
11:17 am
BE11:17am

We believe Disney is still interested in the 61% of Sky that Fox doesn’t already own, but the higher Fox price may make Disney less aggressive on Sky. We think it’s possible, given Comcast’s interest in the floating 61% of Sky, that Disney could encourage Fox to let Comcast win the Sky bid, and save the leverage capacity by not taking on the extra debt from a Sky acquisition. We believe DIS investors would cheer this outcome, as it would effectively reduce the ultimate price Disney would be paying by ~$25bn – approximately the amount it is now offering pay up from its original price to outbid Comcast.
Disney could even then presumably flip Fox’s 39% of Sky to Comcast at the higher share price, which would free up another ~$12bn in cash, assuming Comcast then wants to acquire Sky outright. We expect DIS has an implied price of Sky in its calculation to buy out the 61%, and this may be higher than the 1075p Fox initially offered. As such there is a deal to be had with Comcast, hence the higher price currently on SKY, now trading at 1453p, 16% above Comcast’s 1250p offer price and in line with our target price of 1450p. In fact, Fox has to come back to Comcast with a counter offer for Sky, so this will help determine the eventual price Disney and Comcast will be considering, and Disney has already committed to acquire Sky News as part of the UK deal approval for the Fox offer. This has an implied value of 50p per Sky share.
Sky standalone would certainly be more affordable for Comcast than Fox, and we expect CMCSA shareholders would welcome this less-challenging deal from both a financial and regulatory perspective. Star India could also factor in, though we expect Disney is just as eager to take control of this dominant network and OTT business.

#REF! After TCAP maybe discuss Ocado, really wants to be a tech company, so is dutifully growing the top line but leaving the bottom line behind
BE11:18am

(@Upaswellasdown: Arash gets a nice quiet cubby hole in the corner by the financial services team. I'm next to the vending machines.)

#REF! vending machines? How posh! We have a cardboard box of "multipack do not sell seperately" or imported snacks with an honesty box :)
Arash Massoudi, FT @BE -- two ways to read it 1) we are sitting in a content bubble where the value of entertainment assets is out of line with fundamentals and there will be a sharp reckoning/correction led by Netflix when the music stops. or...
11:21 am
BE11:21am

....... or .........

Arash Massoudi, FT 2) there is a transformational shift in the way media is consumed that gives the consumer more mobility and choice. and the only way to keep that consumer is to give he or she as much of everything that they want in as many different ways.
BE11:22am

Fair.

chad_john But giving them everything doesn't play with the current move towards siloed OTT services, right?
Arash Massoudi, FT so with that world view 1) is a sell -- 2) is a buy
chad_john Unless one company buys everything.

And an elegantly hedged answer. Ta.

I'll let Peel Hunt talk us through the cost stuff, which is the most important stuff.

chad_john Sky (for example) will need to sell their souls to Amazon, Netflix and Spotify - which is great until the prices go up.
BE11:26am

Although actions taken in H1 have delivered additional synergy savings of c£5m (the annualised run rate is now around £65m), after reassessing integration and ongoing investment needs, management has reduced its annualised synergy target from £100m to £75m by the end of 2019. In addition, 2018 profits will be impacted by additional ongoing costs of c£10m, relating to Brexit, MIFID II, regulatory and legal costs and IT security. Broker compensation is also expected to increase in 2018 from 50.5% in 2017 to at least 51%. Near-term additional UK regulatory capital requirements and the refinancing of the RCF are likely to increase finance costs in 2018 to c£35m.

Grouchmonkey @electric dragon. Exactly. That's why there has to be a consolidation phase around the corner, unless people go for a NowTV - type service cherry picking from the whole market on pay as you go basis at a premium price
chad_john Otherwise you've got one subscription for this, one for that, one for sports, one for some movies but this one for other movies and this one for older movies..... argh.
11:27 am
BE11:27am

As a result, EPS for 2018 is expected to be slightly below the bottom end of the range of analyst expectations – we were at the bottom of the range on 34.9p (34.9p to 39.3p) so our reduction will be relatively modest, but the downgrade to consensus is likely to be c7-10%. This will continue into 2019 where the additional ongoing costs will rise to £25m (from £10m in 2017). In addition, TP ICAP plans to make investments of c£15m in Global Broking, Energy & Commodities and the Data & Analytics divisions to accelerate growth. Increased finance costs will move to c£40m in 2019.

alewis2005 Anyone want to see someone get access to 2m lines of EE internal code and analyse it? Of course you do: https://daleys.space/?p=54

Short-term costs associated with Brexit, regulation and IT security are not really a surprise or problem, but forecasts are impacted by the lower synergy targets, higher cost/ income and the need to invest in parts of the business, which lead to a major change to 2019 estimates - early estimate of around a third lower

BE11:29am

While we are still reviewing our forecasts the likely impact on our 2019 forecasts will be around £107m: costs (Brexit, Reg, IT) +£25m, Investment + £15m, cost income +£32m or 2% move on £1.6bn of revenue, Synergies +£10m (worse than our previous target of £85m) and finance costs +£25m. This represents around a third of our previous forecast of £322m of Adj PBT in 2019, although there will be some benefit from recent $ strength.

BE11:41am

In light of today’s numbers we think 2018 consensus EBITDA could be cut by 5-10% at least. Fixed costs are poised to rise in 2He as CFC4 Erith in the UK comes on stream. The group has not provided fresh details on the Kroger contracts in the US, which have yet to be signed. The Kroger deal covers development of 20 CFCs across the US.

pancakes or waffles @rw42 a lot of what you mentioned is already being done, esp in the US
BE11:42am

Ocado has a lot to do in the coming years, with 23 customer fulfilment centres (CFC) already planned for international partners (Casino, Sobeys, ICA and Kroger). Although the story is promising, valuation looks excessive to us with the market implicitly pricing 25 CFCs in addition to the 23 already booked. We also need reassurance on future profitability (lack of details on fees/running costs for international deals – we see no positive signals in today’s results) and execution risks.

pancakes or waffles as in back-end build-out + services that allow for, as an example, tiered pricing
chopper bear was with an ex waitrose director last week ( at a wake of all places) and he seemed pretty confident that amazon will go for them in the next year

#REF! last week I was wondering whether my cynicism over Ocado was OTT, thanks BE for making me feel better.

Want Peel Hunt to do its thing again?

BE11:44am

You know -- the Microsoft of Retail thing.

11:43 am
BE11:44am

It doesn’t happen very often, but we believe Ocado has potential to become the “standard” for retail logistics across all sectors as the operating system of retail. While the company is currently focusing on exclusive contracts within food retail, we would advocate an eventual shift in its focus towards becoming the open industry standard; just like the Windows operating system, which has more than 80% market share as it didn’t restrict itself to just IBM manufactured computers. Niche, closed, exclusive platforms like those from Apple lead to a quick rise, but eventual stagnation, whereas generic, open, standard platforms like Windows and Android supersize.

BE11:45am

Up 6.5% now. Profit? We don't need no stinkin' profit.

We're the Microsoft of Retail.

Equiniti Group PLC (EQN:LSE): Last: 230.50, down 12.5 (-5.14%), High: 235.00, Low: 225.50, Volume: 978.34k

11:48 am
BE11:48am

In recent months, investors have witnessed the almost biblical and hitherto unthinkable collapse of Capita – the waning patriarch of white-collar BPO.

BE11:48am

Biblical? Cripes.

BE11:49am

On Equiniti, it's a proper bear case.

11:49 am
BE11:50am

We think the shares are materially overvalued using multiple methodologies. We review collapsing cash generation and disappointing organic growth; net accrued income has grown 24x faster than sales since IPO; factoring is flattering cash flow and associated reported metrics; deferred income shows limited growth; the cash margin is trending down to single-digit levels; software capitalisation leads to multiple concerns; returns are lower than WACC; endlessly recurring “exceptional charges”; the four IPO "objectives" each appear to have been missed; the proportion of revenues that "recur" may be falling; reclassifications/ re-presentations of the income statement; gearing more than 3x EBITDA when all financing liabilities are included; goodwill = 60%+ of EQN’s market capitalization post the WFSS acquisition and directors have been net sellers of the shares in recent months.

#REF! ah yes I recall the book of Joshua where the tribe underinvests in its platforms in order to continue bushel of wheat dividends to the prophet Woodford
BE11:51am

All criticisms are put to management with the responses included in the note, which is very comprehensive.

BE11:51am

If you're even slightly interested in investing here, I highly recommend giving it a read. Panmure Gordon stuff's available through various retail aggregators.

11:53 am
Kier Group PLC (KIE:LSE): Last: 967.50, up 32.5 (+3.48%), High: 980.50, Low: 925.00, Volume: 340.07k
BE11:54am

Brief statement, possibly in response to some loose talk going round in recent weeks. Full year in line, net debt as previously guided.

Upaswellasdown because it's Danish not Scottish
BE11:55am

Average net debt at £375m is a tad on the high side.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

Previous guidance was for £360m.

BE11:55am

Weather holds back volumes in construction

FATDAZ bye all
BE11:56am

Now normalised.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

Contract stuff unremarkable, pretty much. Here's Barclays.

BE11:56am

Whilst average net debt increased by £55m yoy and was an implied £400m in H2 management remains confident that over the medium term that the £375m outlined today will begin to fall by £20-40m annually, between 2019-2020, whilst maintaining the dividend level and the £500m asset base within the Property and Residential business.

The introduction of a ‘Future Proofing Kier’ strategy is the most significant news today in our view as management seek to deliver a range of operational savings, leveraging the IT Capex investments in 2017/18 and realigning internal management structures and layers to the 3 new divisions.

Whilst details are limited ahead of a more formal outline of the plans with the announcement of FY results in September, management described potential savings for 2020 as ‘material’ on the call with the impact in FY19 anticipated to be broadly neutral (costs in H1 offset by savings in H2). Quick payback suggests a likely focus around central functions and headcount.

BE11:56am

With only limited details it remains early to judge the plans, but with existing Vision 2020 targets forming the foundation of consensus EPS growth expectations of 14% in 2019 an 11% in 2020, it will be interesting to see if there is any upgrade to Vision 2020 targets over the next 3 months given the anticipated materiality or whether such savings are absorbed within existing targets.

The likelihood of non-core disposals has also been introduced today with a likely focus on expediting a reduction in debt levels - we expect more detail around what is core / non-core in the forthcoming results before we can judge the impact and the degree to which the impact on profitability from disposals could be offset by planned savings from the new efficiency programme.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

Numis also.

BE11:58am

Kier's share price has been volatile over the past year on a two-way pull; bears have focussed on average net debt levels (which has intensified post-Carillion), while bulls have focussed on the upper quartile trading performance, double-digit growth and market-leading position of the group. This trading update suggests more of the same for now with increased short-term average net debt expectations, though we applaud the management initiative to enhance profitability and cash generation over and above existing targets. We expect the two-way pull to continue in the short term and fundamental valuation is likely to continue to take a back seat to net debt movements. However, FY results and details of 'Future Proofing Kier' will be key to redressing the balance and unlocking the latent value in the company.

Frances Thank you!
undefined
